Examples:
- Jestem chłopcem (I am a boy)
- Ty jesteś kobietą (You are a woman)
- Ona jest dziewczynką (She is a girl)
- Nie jesteśmy dziecmi (We are not children)
- Jesteście ludźmi (You are people)
- Oni są źli (They are evil)
Notes:
Followed by Narzędnik / Instrumental case
When talking about the future, we use będę, będzie etc which are forms of być. Though będę forms are often better translated as ‘will’ than ‘will be’

Examples:
- Ja piję mleko (I am drinking milk)
- Ty pijesz wino (You are drinking wine)
- On pije wodę (He is drinking water)
- Pijemy kawę (We are drinking coffee)
- Pijecie sok pomarańczowy (You are drinking orange juice)
- Piją wódkę (They are drinking vodka)

- Jem sernik (I am eating cheesecake)
- Jesz jajko (You are eating an egg)
- Kobieta je (A woman is eating)
- Jemy kanapki z szynką (We are eating ham sandwiches)
- Jecie owoce (You are eating fruit)
- Jedzą warzywa (They are eating vegetables)

- Mam psa (I have a dog)
- Masz mleko (You have milk)
- On ma ciasteczka (He has cookies)
- Mamy problem (We have a problem)
- Macie smażonego kurczaka (You have fried chicken)
- Mają wino (They have wine)

Notes:
Followed by Biernik / Accusative case
Can also be used to mean ‘to carry’, used when referring to a repeated / habitual carrying of an item
Used to describe a single, one time trip that hasn’t yet been completed
Used to describe general/multiple trips. A repeated/habitual action
Used to indicate a one time/current carrying of an item
Usually used to mean tidying / arranging as things should be
Modal verb – it requires an infinitive verb to complete it’s role

Meaning: To be able to / Can do
Notes: Modal verb – it requires an infinitive verb to complete it’s role
Modal verb – it requires an infinitive verb to complete it’s role
Modal verb – it requires an infinitive verb to complete it’s role. Also has no past tense, the verb that follows will set the tense
It is used in an impersonal way, where the subject of the sentence (the thing that is liked) is in the nominative case, and the person who likes it is expressed in the dative case.

Examples:
- Ja się dzieje coś dziwnego (Something strange is happening to me)
- Ty się dzieje coś ciekawego (Something interesting is happening to you (singular))
- Ona się dzieje z nią coś złego (Something bad is happening to her)
- My się dzieje wiele rzeczy (A lot of things are happening to us)
- Wy się dzieje coś podejrzanego (Something suspicious is happening to you (plural))
- Oni się dzieje jak zawsze (They are happening as usual)
Notes: Impersonal verb, so it doesn’t have any gendered version. Past tense translates to ‘what was happening’. For impersonal verbs, się preceeds the verb.The verb conjugation then indicates who something is happening to
Used more for emotional / mental wellbeing
Usually used to mean removing dirt / grease etc
